dt: {bc}to constrain by physical, moral, or legal force or by the {d_link|exigencies|exigency} of circumstance

dt.t: felt {it}obliged{/it} to share it with her

dt: {bc}to put in one's debt by a favor or service

dt.t: We are much {it}obliged{/it} for your help.

dt: {bc}to do something as or as if as a favor

dt.t: When he was asked for advice, he {it}obliged{/it}.

pt: {sc}force{/sc} {sc}compel{/sc} {sc}coerce{/sc} {sc}constrain{/sc} {sc}oblige{/sc} mean to make someone or something yield. {sc}force{/sc} is the general term and implies the overcoming of resistance by the exertion of strength, power, or duress.
{sc}compel{/sc} typically suggests overcoming of resistance or unwillingness by an irresistible force.
{sc}coerce{/sc} suggests overcoming resistance or unwillingness by actual or threatened violence or pressure.
{sc}constrain{/sc} suggests the effect of a force or circumstance that limits freedom of action or choice.
{sc}oblige{/sc} implies the constraint of necessity, law, or duty.

et: Middle English {it}obligen, oblischen{/it} "to impose on as a legal or moral duty, bind by oath or contract," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}obliger,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}obligāre{/it} "to tie up, restrain by tying, assign, place under a legal or moral constraint, pledge," from {it}ob-{/it} "toward, facing" + {it}ligāre{/it} "to fasten, bind" {ma}{mat|ob-|}, {mat|ligature|}{/ma}
shortdef: to constrain by physical, moral, or legal force or by the exigencies of circumstance
to put in one's debt by a favor or service

dt: {bc}the obligation of honorable, generous, and responsible behavior associated with high rank or birth

shortdef: the obligation of honorable, generous, and responsible behavior associated with high rank or birth
